start.title: Home
start.header: Appeal an immigration or asylum decision
start.description: We need to ask you a few questions to start your appeal.
requirements: create an account if you haven't already got one
have your Home Office decision letter with you

homeOfficeDetails.htmlLink: Your Home Office details

personalDetails.htmlLink: Your personal details

contactDetails.title: Your contact details
contactDetails.htmlLink: Your contact details

typeOfAppeal.title: Type of appeal
typeOfAppeal.htmlLink: Type of appeal

checkAndSend.title: Check and send your appeal
checkAndSend.htmlLink: Check and send your appeal

contactDetails.header: How do you want us to contact you?
contactDetails.hint: Select at least one of the option below

appealType.pageHint: You can select more than one option

DOB.heading: What is your date of birth?
DOB.title: Date of Birth

nationality.heading: What is your nationality?
nationality.title: Nationality
nationality.stateless: I am stateless (A stateless person is not a citizen of any country).

checkYourAnswers.title: Check your answers
checkYourAnswers.agreement: I believe the information I have given is true

enterPostcode.heading: What is your address?
enterPostcode.title: Address
enterPostcode.manualAddressLink: I want to enter my address manually

postcodeLookup.heading: What is your address?
postcodeLookup.title: Postcode
postcodeLookup.cantFind: I cant find my address in the list

homeOfficePage.title: What is your Home Office reference number?
homeOfficePage.description: You can find this on the top right-hand side of the decision letter.
homeOfficePage.refImageAltText: Image of Home Office decision letter

homeOfficeLetterSent.title: What date was the letter sent?
homeOfficeLetterSent.description: You can usually find this stamped on the envelope of the decision letter. If you don't have the envelope, you can enter the date on the first page of the decision letter.
homeOfficeLetterSent.letterSentImageAltText: Image of Home Office decision letter

homeOfficeAppealLate.title: Your appeal is late
homeOfficeAppealLate.description:
Appeals should be made within 14 days from the date the decision letter was sent.
You may still be able to appeal. Please tell us why your appeal is late below, and provide supporting evidence if you have it.
homeOfficeAppealLate.provideEvidenceDescription: You can upload evidence to support your answers such as letters, photos and documents. If you are taking a picture of a letter, place it on a flat surface and take the picture from above.

successPage.title: Confirmation
successPage.info: You will receive a notification to confirm that the Tribunal has received your appeal application
successPage.noResponse: If you haven't heard from us by {{ date }} call us on 0300 123 1711 or email customer.service@justice.gov.uk
successPage.caseWorker: A case worker will contact you to by {{ date }} to tell you if you can continue with your appeal and what to do next
successPage.tribunalWorker: A Tribunal case worker will contact you to by {{ date }} to tell you what to do next
successPage.readMore: Read more about appealing an immigration or asylum decision
successPage.findOutMore: Find organisations that can you with your appeal

outOfTime.panel: Your have sent an out of time application

inTime.panel:
Your appeal application 
 has been sent

wrongHomeOfficeDecision.title: Home Office Decision
wrongHomeOfficeDecision.heading: Why do you think the Home Office decision is wrong?
wrongHomeOfficeDecision.usefulInfo: It may be helpful to look at the Home Office documents (opens in a new window). They include your decision letter and other information about your case.
wrongHomeOfficeDecision.textTitle: Tell us in your own words - you don't have to have perfect English.
wrongHomeOfficeDecision.bulletOne: Carefully read your Home Office decision letter
wrongHomeOfficeDecision.bulletTwo: Try to understand the parts of your claim the Home Office disagrees with
wrongHomeOfficeDecision.bulletThree: Respond to some or all the things the Home Office disagrees with
wrongHomeOfficeDecision.bulletFour: Tell us about anything new that will affect your case since you made your claim
wrongHomeOfficeDecision.bulletFive: Include supporting evidence where you can. You can do this on the next page
wrongHomeOfficeDecision.bulletLink: Find organisations that can help you with your appeal

caseBuildingSuccess.answer: A Tribunal Caseworker will look at your answer
caseBuildingSuccess.date: The Tribunal Caseworker will contact you by {{ date }} to tell you what to do next
caseBuildingSuccess.questions: If you have any questions about the appeal process, call the Tribunal on 0300 123 1711 or email customer.services@justice.gov.uk

error404.title: Page not found
error404.webAddress: If you typed the web address, check it is correct.
error404.pasted: If you pasted the web address, check you copied the entire address.
error404.link: If the web address is correct or you selected a link or button

error500.title: Service unavailable
error500.header: Sorry, there is a problem with the service
error500.savedAnswers: We saved your answers. They will be available for 30 days.

cookieBanner.content: GOV.UK uses cookies to make the site simpler. Find out more about cookies

validationErrors.homeOfficeRef: The Home Office Number is not correct. Please review it.
validationErrors.atLeastOneTypeOfAppeal: Select at least one of the appeal types
validationErrors.emailFormat: Enter an email address in the correct format, like name@example.com
validationErrors.phoneFormat: Enter a mobile phone number, like 07700 900 982 or +61 2 9999 9999
validationErrors.acceptanceStatement: Select if you believe the information you have given is true.

contactDetails.selectOneOption: Select at least one of the contact options

validationErrors.givenNames: Enter your given name or names
validationErrors.familyName: Enter your family name or names

dateOfBirth.missing: Your date of birth must include a day, month and year
dateOfBirth.incorrectFormat: Enter the date in the correct format
dateOfBirth.inPast: Your date of birth must be in the past

dateLetterSent.missing: Date letter sent must include a day, month and year
dateLetterSent.incorrectFormat: Enter the date in the correct format
dateLetterSent.inPast: The date letter was sent must be in the past

address.line1Required: Enter a building number and street name

homeOfficeReference.required: Enter the Home Office reference number
homeOfficeReference.invalid: Enter the Home Office reference number in the correct format

homeOfficeDecision.required: Enter the reasons you think the Home Office decision is wrong

contactUsErrorLink.link: Contact the Immigration & Asylum Helpline if you need to make changes to your application or speak to someone about your tax credits.

protection.name: Protection
protection.title: Protection (You will be persecuted or harmed in some way if you are returned to your home country)
protection.examples: You might be afraid of the government, police or other groups in your home country because of your nationality, race, religion, political opinion or other reason.

humanRights.name: Human Rights
humanRights.title: Human Rights (You have a family and/or private life in the UK, or a serious medical condition)
humanRights.examples: You might have a partner or children living in the UK, have lived and worked in the UK for a long time or be receiving long-term medical treatment in the UK.

eea.name: European Economic Area
eea.title: European Economic Area (EEA) (You are, or a family member is, an EEA/Swiss national)
eea.examples: You might be, or have been, a family member or carer of an EEA/Swiss national, or have lived in another EEA country with a British family member, and want to either come to or stay in the UK.

revocationOfProtection.name: Revocation of Protection Status
revocationOfProtection.title: Revocation of Protection Status (Your protection status was taken away)
revocationOfProtection.examples: Your protection status might have been taken away if it is believed you no longer need it, you didn’t tell the truth in your claim or you have committed a serious crime.

deprivation.name: Deprivation of Citizenship
deprivation.title: Deprivation of Citizenship (Your British citizenship was taken way)
deprivation.examples: Your British citizenship might have been taken away if it is believed you were involved in behaviours including terrorism, espionage or serious organised crime.
